title: Collaboration Between Department of Old Age Psychiatry and Nursing Homes
description_brief: Dementia is a serious health problem showing an increasing prevalence rate with increasing age. In Norway, about 80% of nursing home patients have dementia. The mean age of nursing home residents in Norway is around 84 years. Disruptive and agitated behaviour affect 30-50% of all individuals with dementia at some point in the course of the illness. In addition, they have a combination of physical and psychological diseases which necessitates a close collaboration between different specialities in medicine and Old Age psychiatry. In collaboration with the communalities, our Old Age psychiatry services want to provide a new approach to this challenge and validate it on patient and personnel level.
explanation_target: Reason: The study description and registry entry describe a non‑drug intervention (education and supervision for nursing‑home staff) aimed at reducing disruptive and agitated behaviour and improving care/quality of life for people with dementia — i.e., targeting neuropsychiatric/behavioural symptoms rather than disease biology or cognition per se. citeturn0search0turn0search4

Act: Key extracted details — Title: "Collaboration Between Department of Old Age Psychiatry and Nursing Homes" (SAM‑AKS); Registry ID: NCT01217541; Lead sponsor: Sykehuset Innlandet HF; Intervention: Education and Supervision for nursing‑home personnel (with control); Primary/secondary outcomes include QUALID, P‑CAT and Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI‑NH), Cornell Scale of Depression in Dementia — all consistent with evaluating effects on behavioural/neuropsychiatric symptoms and staff outcomes. No drug or placebo is listed in the trial record. citeturn0search2turn0search0

Reflect: Classification check — This is a non‑pharmacologic, care‑delivery / staff‑training intervention intended to reduce agitation and other neuropsychiatric symptoms in people with dementia and to improve staff job satisfaction. That matches the defined category "neuropsychiatric symptom improvement." There is no indication of a biologic or small‑molecule disease‑modifying agent or a cognitive‑enhancer drug, so other categories do not fit. citeturn0search1turn0search4
